data.snippet: Vue.js (commonly referred to as Vue; pronounced "view"( is an open-source modelâ€“viewâ€“viewmodel front end JavaScript framework for building user interfaces and single-page applications.( It was created by Evan You and is maintained by him and the rest of the active core team members.( Overview [edit] Vue.js features an incrementally adaptable architecture that focuses on declarative rendering and component composition. The core library is focused on the view layer only.( Advanced features required for complex applications such as routing, state management and build tooling are offered via officially maintained supporting libraries and packages.( [...] ### Reactivity [edit] Vue features a reactivity system that uses plain JavaScript objects and optimized re-rendering. Each component keeps track of its reactive dependencies during its render, so the system knows precisely when to re-render, and which components to re-render.( ### Transitions [edit] Vue provides a variety of ways to apply transition effects when items are inserted, updated, or removed from the DOM. This includes tools to: Automatically apply classes for CSS transitions and animations Integrate third-party CSS animation libraries, such as Animate.css Use JavaScript to directly manipulate the DOM during transition hooks Integrate third-party JavaScript animation libraries, such as Velocity.js "Velocity (JavaScript library)") [...] Features [edit] ### Components [edit] Vue components extend basic HTML elements to encapsulate reusable code. At a high level, components are custom elements to which the Vue's compiler attaches behavior. In Vue, a component is essentially a Vue instance with pre-defined options.( The code snippet below contains an example of a Vue component. data.title: Introduction - Vue.js
data.snippet:
Here is a minimal example:

js

```
import { createApp } from 'vue' import { createApp } from  'vue' createApp({createApp({ data() { data() { return { return { count: 0 count: 0 } } } }}).mount('#app')}). mount('#app')
```

js

```
import { createApp, ref } from 'vue' import { createApp, ref } from  'vue' createApp({createApp({ setup() { setup() { return { return { count: ref(0) count: ref(0) } } } }}).mount('#app')}). mount('#app')
```

template

```
<div id="app">< div  id = "app"> <button @click="count++"> < button  @ click = " count ++ "> Count is: {{ count }} Count is: {{ count }} button>  button>div> div>
```

The above example demonstrates the two core features of Vue: [...] ## The Progressive Framework â€‹

Vue is a framework and ecosystem that covers most of the common features needed in frontend development. But the web is extremely diverse - the things we build on the web may vary drastically in form and scale. With that in mind, Vue is designed to be flexible and incrementally adoptable. Depending on your use case, Vue can be used in different ways:

 Enhancing static HTML without a build step
 Embedding as Web Components on any page
 Single-Page Application (SPA)
 Fullstack / Server-Side Rendering (SSR)
 Jamstack / Static Site Generation (SSG)
 Targeting desktop, mobile, WebGL, and even the terminal [...] Declarative Rendering: Vue extends standard HTML with a template syntax that allows us to declaratively describe HTML output based on JavaScript state.
 Reactivity: Vue automatically tracks JavaScript state changes and efficiently updates the DOM when changes happen.

You may already have questions - don't worry. We will cover every little detail in the rest of the documentation. For now, please read along so you can have a high-level understanding of what Vue offers.

data.title: Why Use Vue.js: Unleash the Power of Frontend Frameworks
data.snippet:
## Key Features of Vue Js

### 1. Lightweight

Vue.js framework has a small 18 KB file size, ensuring fast installation and loading. Its lightweight nature enhances user experience and positively impacts SEO.

### 2. Reactive Data Binding

Vue.js offers a robust reactivity system that keeps your data and UI in sync. With reactive data binding, when the data changes, the view automatically updates. This feature simplifies the process of managing dynamic user interfaces, making it easier to build interactive and responsive applications.

For instance:

Imagine you're developing a real-time chat application. Vue.jsâ€™s reactive data binding ensures that as new messages come, the chat window updates immediately without requiring a manual refresh.

### 3. Component-Based Architecture [...] ### 3. Component-Based Architecture

Vue.js follows component-based architecture, allowing it to encapsulate the structure, styling, and behaviour of a UI into a self-contained component. This approach promotes code reuse, better organization, and easier testing.

For instance:

When building a dashboard with multiple widgets (charts, tables, forms), each widget can be developed as a separate Vue component.

### 4. Two-Way Data Binding

Vue.js supports two-way data binding, which allows for seamless synchronization between the model and the view. This feature is particularly useful in form handling and real-time data applications. Reducing the amount of boilerplate code needed to manage input fields.

For instance: [...] ### 12. Server-Side Rendering (SSR)

Vue.js supports Server-Side Rendering (SSR), which allows you to pre-render components on the server and send fully rendered HTML to the client. SSR improves SEO and reduces the time to the first meaningful paint, especially in content-heavy applications.

For instance:

Using SSR for an e-commerce site ensures quick-loading product pages and better search engine visibility, improving user experience.

### 13. Internationalization (i18n)

Vue.js supports internationalization (i18n) through plugins like vue-i18n, allowing you to create multilingual applications easily. This feature is crucial for applications targeting a global audience.
